page.title: 03Ecology - Land Use
page.content: Many acres of level farmland lie between the Kent estuary and the peat mosses and conifer plantations of Meathop and Foulshaw. Much of this area was cleared and stripped of surface peat over 200 years ago, and Meathop Marsh was later formed by the drainage of estuary silt after the {Furness Railway}opened in 1857. Towards the north-west, Ulpha Fell, a rocky outcrop of Silurian mudstone, rises to 147'. The farms are chiefly devoted to dairy produce. Many large, enclosed fields are grazed by milk cattle - mainly Friesians. Abundant fodder is produced. The fields are frequently fertilized or re-sown. Sheep graze, particularly on parts of Ulpha Fell, and damson trees round the farmhouses provided a small seasonal cash crop.
